text: There are two main types of plankton: phytoplankton, which are plant-like and photosynthesize, and zooplankton, which are animal-like and consume other organisms.
Phytoplankton produce at least 50% of the Earth's oxygen through photosynthesis, making them crucial for life on Earth.
Zooplankton range in size from microscopic organisms to larger species like jellyfish.
Plankton form the base of most aquatic food chains, serving as food for many marine species like fish, whales, and crustaceans.
Some species of plankton can glow in the dark due to bioluminescence, a chemical reaction that produces light.
Plankton are highly sensitive to environmental changes such as water temperature, salinity, and pollution, making them important indicators of ocean health.
Certain species of zooplankton, like copepods, can leap out of the water to escape predators.
Phytoplankton blooms can sometimes be so large that they are visible from space.
Despite their small size, plankton play a major role in the global carbon cycle by absorbing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.
